5.body: No you are not lol. What will they charge you with?

5.author: l3e7haX0R
5.body:
Obstruction of traffic. At least here in Texas. Each state is different though.

Officially, there are speed limit signs posted which is supposed to be what the max speed limit is. However in practice it's more nuanced than that.

Texas lawbook states that an unreasonable speed is an offense, which leaves ambiguity to what unreasonable is. If everyone is going 90, and I'm going 60 it can be argued that I'm going the unreasonable speed as I'm basically creating an obstruction to the flow of traffic. Same can be said the other way around, if the speed limit is 70 and everyone is doing 50, but I'm doing 70, there's a chance I can be pulled over and given a ticket. It sounds dumb, and it is, but the laws are ambiguous and open to a lot of interpretation.

This is also the same reason why cops here can give tickets to people who go the speed limit in the left lane. It's expected to be the fast lane for passing, and if you're just camping and blocking the lane for passing you can get a ticket for that too.

5.author: Henrikusan
5.body:
Im aware of the concept but every reasonable interpretation of it(and the word of the law where i live) applies it only when you are below the speed limit. The internet, which i consulted after multiple people told me i was wrong without saying how, also consistently states that it can be illegal to drive significantly slower than the fliw of traffic if, and only if, the flow of traffic is at or below the speed limit. 
If you go at the speed limit in the left lane the issue isn't that you are at the speed limit, the problem is that you are in the left lane and not passing anyone. If there is a truck in the right lane going below the speed limit then passing that truck in the left lane at the speed limit is not illegal in any way im aware of. After passing him you should then switch back into the right lane.

5.author: l3e7haX0R
5.body:
I mean it really is dependent on the state. I offered Texas since that's my state, but your state may be different. In Oklahoma for example, they have a max and a min speed limit, iirc based on my personal travels.

Mileage may vary, laws are different, if you're curious about your own state I would suggest talking to someone familiar with your state laws. Reddit isn't confined to your own state or country, so best to not always assume what Reddit says is true for you. Just offering my 2 cents.

5.author: Henrikusan
5.body:
You seem to try to be nonconfrontational so im sorry but all these people telling me im wrong and then not backing up their claims are annoying me. 
Texas lawbook does not say that unreasonably low speeds are illegal. It says that driving(among other things) in a way that obstructs the road is illegal. If you drive at the speed limit then other people behind you can drive at the speed limit which is the indended use of the road therefore you are not obstructing it. 
I have not been able to find a single article or law that states that following the flow of traffic could have priority over following the speed limit for texas or anywhere else. I have however easily found multiple articles cautioning that breaking the speed limit is breaking the law under any circumstances. The law is also quite clear on this although texas is actually a tiny bit more lenient here than other states. If you drive at or slightly below the speed limit under normal weather conditions(in adverse conditions you may be required to drive slower)  you are not breaking any laws. You might get pulled over if a cop thinks you are suspiciously cautious, which might indicate drunkenness but if his suspicion is unfounded there is nothing you could be charged with. 
Merging onto a highway is the only exception i can come up with as safety during the merge requires you to match the speed of traffic but afterwards you can slowly slow down to the speed limit if the slowest lane is faster than the speed limit.

8.author: The-Hyruler
8.body:
>analogy - "a comparison between one thing and another, typically for the purpose of explanation or clarification."

If you don't think my position is comparable there's no reason to ever raise the question to begin with. 

If you wanted to know if I think it's okay to slaughter a dog to eat it you could have just asked me that, but that's not what you did. 

I strongly suggest that you think your arguments and questions through a lot harder in the future.

8.author: Sadmiral8
8.body:
I'm not saying the actions are comparable, I'm saying the logic behind the actions is comparable and so is the outcome of enjoyment.. Even so the actions are actually comparable when you think about it. I'm not saying they are the same thing, but that's where you could and should make an argument on why the other is wrong and the other is moral.

I'm also not asking whether it's okay to slaughter a dog to eat, I'm asking if it's okay to kill a dog if you get joy out of it, not taste pleasure.

Do you actually not understand where I'm getting at? It just seems to me that you are either acting dumb for a reason or being dishonest and just wasting time.

8.author: The-Hyruler
8.body:
Except it is not. I clearly stated I'm against mistreatment of animals. 

Unless of course you don't consider kicking an animal to death as mistreatment. In which case I suggest you see a medical professional.

8.author: Sadmiral8
8.body: So you don't think that killing an animal who doesn't want to die is mistreatment?

8.author: Sadmiral8
8.body: So that's the reductio, weird that you got upset at the analogy I presented earlier then.

8.author: The-Hyruler
8.body:
Because you specified the way of killing. 

I don't mind the killing of an animal, let's just stick to a dog, but I do mind the method. 

I've had plenty of dogs put down over the years, and amazingly not one of them was by kicking it. 

Astounding how the majority of people understand this simple concept, yet you struggle to even grasp it.

8.author: Sadmiral8
8.body:
We are not talking about euthanasia for crying out loud..

Slaughterhouses don't pet farmed animals to death, or are you actually that naive?

Are you saying that it's okay to kill an animal that is perfectly healthy that is at roughly 20% of their lifespan that ***does not want to die*** for enjoyment?

8.author: The-Hyruler
8.body:
There you go again... Adding details you shouldn't. 

The answer for what you just asked, no. 

The answer for what you just asked after we remove the last two words, yes.

8.author: Sadmiral8
8.body: Yet at the very beginning your justification for consuming animal products was taste pleasure was it not?

8.author: The-Hyruler
8.body:
That was part of it, I said it wasn't *just* to stay alive. 

Typically that means there's multiple reasons. Which is why I've spoken in more general terms as to not make stupid statements like "iT's oKaY tO KiLl fOR eNjOYmEnT". 

If you want anyone to take you seriously you need to pay attention and at the very least not sound like someone who's new to the planet.

8.author: Sadmiral8
8.body:
Think you didn't mean just to stay alive there.

If you say your justification for eating animal products is taste, and I go with that, I'm somehow wrong? You could always just tell me your other justifications and answer the question.

Funny thing is that you are the one refusing to answer the questions and being generally rude, while calling me dishonest and rude.

8.author: The-Hyruler
8.body:
I'm answering your questions, I'm just not giving you more than you're asking for. 

So far your questions have been stupid boarding on offensive, or too vague to actually warrant any meat (pun intended). 

If you wanna know something feel free to ask without inserting some unnecessary detail and without being absurd about it. 

Like with the question you just asked for instance, it's absurd to ask as I've literally already listed a few reasons for why I think it's okay to eat meat. 

You're the one who don't seem to understand how basic argumentation works. I'm just refusing to solo carry the conversation with you simply strawmaning my position and asking absurd questions.

8.author: Sadmiral8
8.body:
Alright, here we go.

You say you are against animals being mistreated. Could you tell me what justifications you have for eating animal products?

8.author: The-Hyruler
8.body: I don't consider taking eggs away from a chicken to be a type of mistreatment. Nor do I think milking a cow is mistreatment.

8.author: Sadmiral8
8.body:
Are you a vegetarian? 

Milk actually requires for the calves to be separated from their mother's quickly after birth and generally in the first 24 hours. This causes distress to the cows since they are maternal being just like us. Also the calves if they are male are most likely killed off soon after for veal, and the females get the same treatment as their mother's did. The dairy cows are also killed for meat when they are approximately 6 years old, their natural lifespan is roughly 15-20 years.

Egg laying hens are commercially treated badly in factory farms, and even in better conditions if they are born male they are sorted to a macerator which grinds them up alive.

Do you think these practices are ethical, or would you categorize them as mistreating the animals?

8.author: The-Hyruler
8.body:
I am not a vegetarian, and this is again an example of a question that's so stupid it's bordering offensive. If you'd paid proper attention you'd know the answer already. 

And who said I support any of that? 

Maybe you should have asked that question at the end and just left out the two middle paragraphs.

8.author: Sadmiral8
8.body:
Then why only use those two scenarios as examples? And that's exactly my question here.. I didn't say you support any of that, I'm asking you. The two paragraphs are there to give you context on what could be wrong in eating eggs and dairy.

You were and are being incredibly dishonest and rude, even when I tried playing nice. I guess you don't actually want to answer the questions since you know where they would lead.

You are saying you are against the mistreatment of animals but never give any good reason of why you funding the incredibly exploitative and cruel industry that is the animal agriculture, because you know you don't have one.
